questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment that uses Direct Routing and a single carrier.
You deploy a new Session Border Controller (SBC) that shows as healthy in the Microsoft Teams admin center.
You place a test call over the new SBC, and the call succeeds.
When you attempt to transfer the call, the transfer fails. A portion of the SIP ladder is shown in the exhibit. (Click the Exhibit tab.)
//IMG//

What is a possible cause of the issue?

choices.B: The Refer on the SBC is misconfigured.
choices.C: NOTIFY is enabled in the SIP options of the SBC.
choices.A: The SSL certificate of the SBC is incorrect.
choices.D: The carrier rejects the format of the forwarded FROM number.

discussion.content: B is correct. A: App Setup Policy is irrelevant for calling. C: SBCs are used, so it's direct routing, no emergency address needed. D: if EV was disabled, there would be no dialpad.

Selected Answer: B
B is clear

Selected Answer: B
It can only be routing policy the prohibits external calling.

Selected Answer: B
B it is. Since the dial pad is being used to make internal calls so these are not Teams 1:1 calls. And voice routing policy gets applied to users in Teams.

choices.D: Enterprise Voice is disabled for the user.
choices.B: The user has the incorrect voice routing policy applied.
choices.A: The user has the incorrect Teams app setup policy applied.
choices.C: The user is missing a validated emergency address.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment that has 10 offices. Each office has a Session Border Controller (SBC).
A user reports that she can make internal calls by using the dial pad, but cannot use the dial pad to make external calls.
What is a possible cause of the issue?

You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You are deploying Direct Routing.
All users have a SIP URI in the format of user@contoso.com. The Session Border Controller (SBC) is named sbc.voice.contoso.com.
When troubleshooting errors on the SBC, you receive the warning shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

What is a possible cause of the issue?

choices.C: Only TLS 1.0 is enabled on the SBC.
choices.A: The certificate does not match the FQDN on the SBC.
choices.D: Microsoft 365 Phone System licenses are not assigned to the users.
choices.B: The firewall blocks inbound traffic on port 443 to the SBC.

comments.content: C has been updated to TLS 1.2 and it has also updated answer A to something like " vanity domain of voice.contoso.com has been added. "

discussion.content: Just passed the exam today. This question was included and Microsoft updated the the answer C to TLS 1.2....Thus leaving A to be the only correct answer.

comments.content: Did you take the exam recently? how many questions from this set please?

discussion.content:
answers has been updated.
New Answer should be: Firewall blocks Signaling Port

A is correct. B and D doesnt make any sense. In my testlab with an audiocodes ve sbc tls 1.2 is preconfigured for teams in the sbc wizard. So you only need to add the correct certificate to the Teams tls context with CN = Device Name

should not be C? If the TLS connection is closed right away and SIP options are not received from the SBC, or if 200 OK is not received from the SBC, then the problem might be with the TLS version. The TLS version configured on the SBC should be 1.2 or higher.

comments.content: On an audiocodes sbc there is Tls 1.2 preselected if you are running the sbc Wizard.

questions.question_text:
You have Microsoft Teams Phone handsets.
You need to receive an alert when a handset of an executive goes offline.
What should you do in the Microsoft Team admin center?

choices.C: Register the handsets by using remote provisioning.
choices.B: Create a configuration profile for IP phones.
choices.A: Create a Teams app setup policy and assign the policy to all executives.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You use Direct Routing with a Survivable Branch Appliance (SBA) at a site.
The site experiences an extended internet outage.
Which three PSTN calling scenarios are possible during the outage? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.E: hold and resume of PSTN calls

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CDE
correct answer is CDE:

When the Microsoft Teams client is in offline mode, the following calling-related functionality is available:
Making PSTN calls via local SBA/SBC with media flowing through the SBC.
Receiving PSTN calls via local SBA/SBC with media flowing through the SBC.
Hold and Resume of PSTN calls.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/direct-routing-survivable-branch-appliance

Selected Answer: CDE
UCExpert is right. CDE

Selected Answer: CDE
correct answer is CDE
